body: You’ve heard of the four-minute mile and, perhaps, the race to dip under two hours in the marathon. In Formula 1, it’s all about breaking the two-second barrier. Or at least it was, until at the 2013 US grand prix, the Red Bull pit crew replaced Mark Webber’s tyres in 1.923 seconds, beating their own world record. Increasingly, the tech and know-how required to achieve such a feat of choreography has created a science. And pit-stop methodology is being applied to other worlds where speed and accuracy in a confined space can be the difference between life and death – or efficiently made toothpaste and less efficiently made toothpaste. Doctors from the University Hospital of Wales have visited the Williams F1 team to improve its performance in resuscitating newborn babies. They learned how to better organise their instruments trolley and create a floorplan with places marked for each team member. “We’ve re-audited the streamlined trolley after six months and we found a significant improvement in the accessibility and the organisation of the equipment,” specialist registrar Rachel Hayward told BBC Wales, explaining that this had had a knock-on effect on speed. “They’ve also learned how to use hand signals, which is what we do because of the engine noise,” says Clare Williams, the deputy team principal of Williams (and daughter of its founder Sir Frank Williams). “And they’re considering slow-motion video analysis, which we use to improve our pit stops.” The physical and mental demands of a two-second stop are such that F1 teams employ specialists to train and prepare mechanics, who must be as agile and focused as the drivers. Adam Hill is a surgeon and engineer at McLaren Applied Technologies, a spin-off from the McLaren F1 team. He’s responsible for things such as “task sequencing” and “designing out failure”, as well as the care of the mechanics, who work under stress in a risky environment (less so since the 2009 ban on mid-race refuelling, which allowed pit times to drop significantly). But McLaren has also installed a version of the telemetrics it uses to check car performance to monitor heart patients at Birmingham Children’s Hospital. “And when Great Ormond Street were so frustrated that they couldn’t get a child from the operating theatre 100 metres to intensive care on a Saturday because it required 17 people, they contacted us,” Hill adds. Drugs giant GSK used McLaren’s pit-stop skills to cut the time it takes to switch toothpaste flavours in one of its production lines from 39 to 15 minutes, allowing it to produce an extra 6.7m tubes a year. But can we pit stop everyday life, saving seconds in pasta preparation or the school run? Absolutely, Hill says. “We hear so much about disruptive innovation but very little about incremental innovation. I’m obsessed with making improvements in everything I do, measuring it and analysing that data.” Away from the track, he also takes this approach with his kids. “It helps me modify their behaviour, whether it’s eating their carrots or going to bed earlier,” he says.
webTitle: Can the science of F1 pit stops transform everyday life?
